column8: State DAP chairman Chong Chieng Jen is puzzled by SUPP Youth chief Tan Kai’s challenge to him to lodge a police report over the alleged RM1 million donation from Prime Minister Datuk Seri Najib Tun Razak via 1Malaysia Development Berhad (1MDB).He said he wanted Tan to explain what purpose would lodging a police report serve when the Royal Malaysia Police (PDRM) and Attorney-General’s (AG) Chambers had stated that they would not investigate and charge individuals allegedly having any involvement in 1MDB.“PDRM and AG’s Chambers have made it clear that they will not investigate and press charges, so what is the purpose of lodging a police report?” he queried at a press conference here yesterday.Chong, who is Bandar Kuching MP and Kota Sentosa assemblyman, said not only was Tan’s challenge uncalled for but that Tan was also arrogant enough to extend the challenge knowing for a fact that the authorities would not take action.He said Tan’s challenge was akin to some quarters involved in illegal activities in broad daylight with no fear of being caught by the authorities.He said world-renowned celebrities had returned gifts allegedly purchased with money from 1MBD, while banks in many countries had been sued and fined and bank officers sentenced to jail for being involved in the scheme.“But in Malaysia, the AG cannot prosecute the MO1. This has brought shame to Malaysia,” said Chong.Chong said former SUPP president Tan Sri Peter Chin did issue a press statement in May last year to explain the matter but, based on the statement, did not deny the receipt of RM1 million from Najib to SUPP.“For a party president facing such allegation but cannot deny in a clear term, that is tantamount to admission that SUPP did receive the amount.“(SUPP president Datuk) Dr Sim (Kui Hian) on the same occasion (last year) said he did not know anything, just pushed it to Peter Chin,” asserted Chong.He said even though the donation was not regarded as illegal in Malaysia, it should be seen as immoral.He opined that a political party like SUPP should practise a higher standard of decency, morality and integrity compared to celebrities.“I’m just puzzled why they cannot return the RM1 million, which is just a small amount to SUPP.”http://www.theborneopost.com/2017/07/03/po...tform=hootsuite
